prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R Leo CO, CN, SO, H2CO

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We need to detect as many molecular lines as possible to perform the comparison between the observations of the envelopes of R Leo and U Hya. Then, we are interested in the widest spectral windows. The FWHM of the lines we expect to observe ranges between 5 and 12km/s. A spectral resolution lower than ~2.6km/s is not enough to resolve the narrowest lines. If we need to increase the S/N of the broadest lines, we will bin several velocity channels.

The goals of our proposal are (1) to observe the largest number of lines in the inner layers of the O-rich envelope of R Leo and of the C-rich envelope of U Hya, and compare them in order to understand how the Galactic UV radiation field affects the chemistry of the envelope of these stars; and (2) to map the innemost envelope of R Leo, where a structure that could be an outflow or a rotating disc seems to exist. To achieve these goals, we need a very high angular resolution but recovering the emission of large scale structures is not needed.

A RMS of 2mJy/beam is enough to observe the emission of CO(2-1) coming from the shells close to the central star. The FWHM of the lines are expected to be ~12km/s. With this FWHM, a spectral resolution of 2.6km/s is enough to sample the observed lines. Although the S/N is small, we will able to analyze the emission coming from the inner shells of the envelope. The analysis of the emission coming from shells at larger distances can be performed after degrading the angular resolution. If a larger S/N is needed, we can bin several velocity channels.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R Leo HCN, H13CN J=4-3 CS J=7-6 HCO+ J=4-3

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We need to detect as many molecular lines as possible to perform the comparison between the observations of the envelopes of R Leo and U Hya. Then, we are interested in the widest spectral windows. The FWHM of the lines we expect to observe ranges between 5 and 10km/s. A spectral resolution lower than ~1.6km/s is not enough to resolve the narrowest lines. If we need to increase the S/N of the broadest lines, we will bin several velocity channels after the observations.

The main goal of our proposal is to observe the largest number of lines in the inner layers of the O-rich envelope of R Leo and of the C-rich envelope of U Hya, and compare them in order to understand how the Galactic UV radiation field affects the chemistry of the envelope of these stars. To achieve this goal, we need a very high angular resolution but recovering the emission of large scale structures is not needed.

A RMS of 3mJy/beam is enough to observe the emission of HCN(4-3) coming from the shells close to the central star. The FWHM of the lines are expected to be smaller than ~12km/s since these lines are formed close to the star. With this FWHM, a spectral resolution of 1.6km/s is enough to sample the observed lines. Although the S/N is small, we will able to analyze the emission coming from the inner shells of the envelope. The analysis of the emission coming from shells at larger distances can be performed after degrading the angular resolution. If a larger S/N is needed, we can bin several velocity channels.

We need to detect as many molecular lines as possible to perform the comparison between the observations of the envelopes of R Leo and U Hya. Then, we are interested in the widest spectral windows. The FWHM of the lines we expect to observe ranges between 5 and 12km/s. A spectral resolution lower than ~2.2km/s is not enough to resolve the narrowest lines. If we need to increase the S/N of the broadest lines, we will bin several velocity channels.

The main goal of our proposal is to observe the largest number of lines in the inner layers of the O-rich envelope of R Leo and of the C-rich envelope of U Hya, and compare them in order to understand how the Galactic UV radiation field affects the chemistry of the envelope of these stars. To achieve this goal, we need a very high angular resolution but recovering the emission of large scale structures is not needed.

A RMS of 2mJy/beam is enough to observe the emission of SiO(6-5) coming from the shells close to the central star. The FWHM of the lines are expected to be ~12km/s. With this FWHM, a spectral resolution of 2.2km/s is enough to sample the observed lines. The S/N is enough to observe the SiO line. However, other lines that will be observed with this setup could need improve the S/N. If a larger S/N is needed, we can bin several velocity channels.

The goals of our proposal is to observe the largest number of lines in the inner layers of the O-rich envelope of R Leo and of the C-rich envelope of U Hya, and compare them in order to understand how the Galactic UV radiation field affects the chemistry of the envelope of these stars. To achieve this goal, we need a high angular resolution but recovering the emission of large scale structures is not needed.

The FWHM of the lines we expect to observe ranges between 5 and 12km/s. A spectral resolution lower than ~2.2km/s is not enough to resolve the narrowest lines. If we need to increase the S/N of the broadest lines, we will bin several velocity channels.

The main goal of our proposal is to observe the largest number of lines in the inner layers of the O-rich envelope of R Leo and of the C-rich envelope of U Hya, and compare them in order to understand how the Galactic UV radiation field affects the chemistry of the envelope of these stars. To achieve this goal, we need a very high angular resolution but recovering the emission of large scale structures is not needed.

A RMS of 2mJy/beam is enough to observe the emission of SiO(6-5) coming from the shells close to the central star. The FWHM of the lines are expected to be ~12km/s. With this FWHM, a spectral resolution of 2.2km/s is enough to sample the observed lines. The S/N is enough to observe the SiO line. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The gas-phase chemistry in the envelopes of the AGB stars strongly depends on the abundance ratio C/O. An excess of C compared to O (C/O>1; C-rich) turns the circumstellar envelopes in molecular factories contrarily to what happen in O-rich envelopes (C/O<1), which are unable to create a large variety of molecules. In optically thin envelopes, where the Galactic UV radiation field can penetrate dissociating and ionizing neutral molecules, the chemistry could significantly change due to the new chemistry triggered by the radicals and ions. The main goal of this proposal is to compare the molecular richness of the C-rich star U Hya and the O-rich star R Leo to determine how the Galactic UV radiation field affects the circumstellar chemistry. Additionally, these observations could help us to determine the nature of a still unknown structure in the innermost envelope of R Leo discovered several decades ago.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Group of Molecular Astrophysics, ICMM CSIC
Group of Molecular Astrophysics, ICMM CSIC
